In addition to his disability income of $112 monthly and the retirement pension of his mother in the amount of $134 per month, for the past ten years he’s been doing agriculture and livestock to earn an income for his family. He plants lucerne, shamrock and fodder for his animals on the 5000 square meters of land his family owns and also plants some veggies and grains for family use. Currently he’s got two dairy cows, two sows and 15 chickens and sells calves and piglets.
He will put the loan he is requesting from you to use to do the roofing of the place where he lives.

loans.use: to do the roofing of his family's place of living as shown in the photograph. They fall below the national poverty level.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: install a brick floor in his home

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to invest in bricks, iron, cement, sand, gravel, and beams for the expansion of his home.

loans.name: Samson

texts.en:
Thanks for your support and act of kindness. You just don't know how you helped Samson. With the amount of PHP 50,000 that you recently lent him, he was able to add more food stuffs and grocery items in his small sari-sari store business, thus enabling him to earn a little higher profit than usual, which he used to supply the needs of his household.

This time, he wants to ask again for another PHP 50,000 loan. He will be utilizing this to purchase more products to sell in his variety store. With this, he and his family can surely benefit, having the opportunity to be a little bit better every day. If he is be able to save enough money, then he could finally start building his dreams and expand his business. He envisions that someday he would be handling his own branch.

He meets every week with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages needed in his business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase spare parts and do quality service and maintenance for the motorbike to meet clients' needs, for more income so as to improve family living standards.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: pay medical expenses and rehabilitation for his son who was injured at work

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is 31 years old, married and blessed with three children. He is a farmer and has been in the business for four years. He will use the loan to buy farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizer for use on his farm. He hopes this will enable him to get more farm produce to sell. He plans to use the anticipated profits to repay the loan and educate his children. His future hopes are to improve his farming, make more income and support his family.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizer for use on his farm and he hopes this will enable him to get more farm produce to sell.

loans.name: Dúo Lomas De San Cristóbal Group

texts.es: Dúo Lomas de San Cristóbal, este grupo esta conformado por Suly es madre de dos hijos menores de edad los cuales van al colegio de su comunidad. El esposo de suly es tapicero y le apoya en sus sueños. suly es comerciante de tamales los cuales hace dos veces por semana y menciona irle muy bien en su negocio. suly solicita un crédito para comprar más ollas e invertir en su negocio de tamales. el sueño de suly es tener un negocio por mayor y por pedidos de sus tamales y espera lograrlo muy pronto, con la ayuda de Fape y kiva
texts.en:
"Dúo Lomas de San Cristóbal" is a group and one of its members is named Suly, a mother of two younger children who go to school in the community. Her husband is an upholsterer and supports her in her dreams. Suly is a merchant of tamales which she makes twice a week and things are going well with her business.

Suly is requesting a loan to purchase more pots and invest in her tamale business. Her dream is to have a wholesale business through orders of her tamales. She expects to achieve it soon with the help of Fape and Kiva.

loans.use: to make and sell tamales.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to improve her farming activity through application of modern farming technologies, especially the use of fortified fertilizer.

loans.name: Mirvat

texts.en:
Mirvat is a 45-year-old single woman who started 13 years ago working in preparing "Mouneh" to cover her needs and expenses. She also sells clothes from her house as a second source of her income. 

Mirvat gained experience in preparing "Mouneh" from her mother, who was well known in their region. Mirvat has professional skills in this domain and she has a good reputation among her customers for her delicious "Mouneh". 

Today she is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to buy the necessary foodstuff to increase her production and satisfy her customers' needs in the upcoming holy month of Ramadan.

Mirvat hopes to expand her business more in the future to increase her income and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy necessary foodstuff to increase her production in the upcoming holy month of Ramadan

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy more stock of fruits

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is a married woman. She describes herself to be determined. 

She operates a pub where she sells drinks. She has been involved in this business for five years. Her business is located in an area with potential and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital. 

She will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy more stock of drinks. Her business goal is to be financially stable within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will expand business and have  a bigger premise. 

This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy more stock of drinks

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a widowed woman. She has five children. She describes herself to be determined. She operates a retail business where she sells charcoal. She has been involved in this business for 20 years. Her business is located in a good place and her primary customers are individuals. 

Beatrice will use the Kes 50,000 loan to buy more stock of charcoal. Her business goal is to expand the business within five years. 

She hopes that in the future she will educate her children. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy more stock of charcoal

loans.name: Rayi's Group

texts.en:
Rayi is aged 41 years and a mother of four children and three of them are in school while the other one is too young to get in school. 

She is a rural villager living in Mondulkiri province. To overcome her family’s hardship, she grows cassava for sale and has worked on  another farm for a fee for about three years. Through these businesses, she could earn around 41,800 KHR per day. 

Now she leads a group to take a Kiva loan via VisionFund to pay the plowing fee for her farming. She hopes this loan will help her to improve her family’s living condition.

loans.use: to pay the plowing fee

loans.name: Fima

texts.en:
Fima is a married woman with three children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Fima is 43 years old and has two children who are currently in school.

Fima has a food vending business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 30,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy ingredients like vegetables, spices, meat, noodles, fish, etc. for her business.

Fima has been in this business for 25 years. In the future, she would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy ingredients like vegetables, spices, meat, noodles, fish, etc. for her business

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy is a married woman. She has 2 children. She describes herself as determined. She operates a restaurant, and has been involved in this business for 3 years. Her business is located in a strategic place and her primary customers are the general public. She will use the Kes 80,000 loan to buy more stock of ingredients for preparing food. Her business goal is to be the best restaurant in town within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will be a successful business lady. This is her third  loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank; her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy more stock of ingredients for preparing food

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to improve her farming through application of modern farming technologies especially use of fertilizers and certified maize seedlings

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase stock of timber to make carpentry items such as chairs and tables to sell and meet client needs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to improve her farming activity through application of modern farming technologies like greenhouse planting

loans.name: Rizza

texts.en:
Rizza is a married woman with two children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. She is 29 years old and has one child who is currently in school.

Rizza has a coconut wine vending business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 15,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional containers of coconut wine to sell to her customers.

Rizza has been in this business for 18 years. She would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional containers of coconut wine to sell to her customers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more stock of second-hand clothes to meet her clients' demand.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a married man. He has 2 children. He describes himself as ambitious. He operates a dairy farm, and has been involved in this business for 4 years. His business is located in a good area. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds. He will use the Kes 51,000 loan to buy a dairy cow. He hopes that in the future, he will have a good business. This is his fourth loan with SMEP Microfinance bank; his previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Bertha

texts.en: Bertha is 43 years old, married and blessed with 9 children. She is a dairy farmer and has been in this business for 14 years. She will be using the loan to buy feed for her dairy cows and hopes this will enable her to get more milk to sell. She plans to use the anticipated profits to repay the loan and educate her children. Her future hopes are to improve her dairy farming, make more income and support her family.

loans.use: To buy feed for her dairy cows so as to get more milk to sell.

loans.name: Moises

texts.es:
Moisés es un pequeño cafetalero de la zona norte de Nicaragua. Por mucho tiempo trabajó en la siembra y cosecha de musáceas y frutas, pero desde hace 15 años cuenta con su pequeña parcela de café la cual maneja bajo procesos de certificación como comercio justo.

Con el apoyo técnico de la asociación a la cual está afiliado, ha creado un plan de manejo nutricional para su cafetal, por lo que requiere el financiamiento para comprar los insumos agrícolas que le permitan tener una buena producción este año, y con ello mejorar económicamente las condiciones de su familia.

Su meta es continuar mejorando su pequeña finca y ampliando sus áreas de café, para seguir creciendo y generando oportunidades para su familia.
texts.en:
Moisés is a small coffee producer in the northern area of Nicaragua.  He has worked for a long time raising and harvesting bananas and fruits, but has spent the last 15 years with his small parcel of coffee, which he manages under the fair trade certification.

With technical support from the association, to which he belongs, he has created a nutritional management plan for his coffee crop and needs a loan to buy supplies that will allow for a good production this year.  This way he will be able to improve his family’s financial situation.

His goal is to continue improving his small farm and expanding his coffee plot so he can continue growing and creating opportunities for his family.

loans.use: to buy farming supplies.

loans.name: Maria Celina

texts.es:
María Celina tiene 24 años de edad, tiene hogar estable al lado de su cónyuge y 3 menores hijos en el distrito de Santo Tomas, su población se dedica a la agricultura, comercio y ganadería, ubicada en la Provincia de Cutervo, que pertenece a la Región Cajamarca, sierra norte del Perú.

Ella se dedica a la agricultura, específicamente cultivo de maíz amarillo criollo, adicionalmente cría animales menores como gallinas, patos, cuyes y cerdos. Ha solicitado un préstamo para la compra de tres cerdos pequeños para engorde de los mismos y su posterior venta, de esta manera ella espera generar mayores ingresos para su familia, lo que le va a permitir mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Maria Celina, 24, and her partner have a stable home with their three young children in the district of Santo Tomas. The people there work in agriculture, cattle and commerce. Santo Tomas is located in the province of Cutervo in the Cajamarca region, in the northern mountains of Peru.

Maria Celina is a farmer. She grows yellow creole corn and also raises small animals like chickens, ducks, guinea pigs and pigs. She has asked for a loan to buy 3 small pigs so that she can fatten them up and later sell them. This will help her generate more income for her family and improve their quality of life.

loans.use: to buy 3 small pigs to fatten and later sell.

loans.name: Fatoumata's Group

texts.fr: Fatoumata qui se trouve sur la photo au centre, tenant un bébé dans les bras, est membre d’un groupe de 13 agriculteurs inscrits à myAgro, vivant et travaillant dans le village de Konoko au sud-est de Bamako au Mali. Fatoumata, âgée de 45 ans, est la mère de 3 enfants âgés de 17 à 20 ans, dont 2 d’entre eux sont actuellement scolarisés.  L’ancrage de la tradition familiale dans la pratique agricole, source principale de revenu et de l’autosuffisance alimentaire du foyer, mais aussi l'agriculture lui permet d'assurer l'autosufficance pour sa famille, ont incité Fatoumata à exercer cette activité depuis maintenant 30 ans. Elle a mentionné que, "on ne peut pas distinguer du mauvais graine parmis les graines." Fatoumata cultive l'arachide, le riz sur sa parcelle mais doit faire face en tant qu’agricultrice à des difficultés telles que le manque de pluie, de matériel agricoles et d'engrais de qualité. Elle a partagé que, "la parole d'un vieux est sacre." Fatoumata entame sa première année avec myAgro, et s'est inscrite en raison du système de paiement et des semences de qualité, ainsi que des formations et techniques agricoles. Elle a exprimé que, "tant qu'on joue le tam-tam ce qui ne veut pas danser finira de danser." Cette année Fatoumata effectue des paiements pour acheter un paquet myAgro de semences OPV et d'engrais pour la culture d'arachide afin d’augmenter ses rendements sur sa parcelle de 0.0625 hectare. Cela fait maintenant 20 ans que Fatoumata cultive l'arachide pour sa valeur vivrière, expliquant que l’arachide est directement consommable par la famille et est utilisée comme sauce de base dans l’alimentation et aussi pour sa valeur commerciale, car l’arachide est un aliment qu’elle vend sur le marché. Elle a expliqué que, "on s'assoie avant de se coucher." Fatoumata planifie avec l’augmentation de ses rendements et de son revenu  de faire de l'élevage et d'étendre la surface cultivée . Elle a mentionné que, "le recipient pour receuillir le miel est toujours en haut." Enfin Fatoumata espère aussi pouvoir couvrir les frais scolaires des enfants ainsi que construire une maison pour la famille.
texts.en:
Fatoumata is the woman holding a baby in the middle of the photo.  She is a member of a group of 13 farmers registered with myAgro, who live and work in the village of Konoko, located south-east of Bamako, Mali.  Fatoumata is 45 years old and the mother of three children whose ages range between 17 and 20. Two of her children currently attend school. 

The family tradition is anchored in agricultural practice, an activity which constitutes the main source of income and provides food self-sufficiency for the family. For this reason, Fatoumata decided to become a farmer 30 years ago. She says that "one cannot distinguish bad seeds from all seeds." She grows groundnut and rice on her plot of land. As a farmer, however, she faces challenges such as the lack of rain, of farming tools and of high-quality fertilizers.  She also says that "an old's man words are sacred". 

Fatoumata is starting her first year with myAgro. She decided to join because of the payment system, the high-quality seeds and the technical farming training. She says that "as long as you keep playing the drums, even the one who doesn't want to dance will start dancing."  This year, she will be making payments to purchase a myAgro package of OPV (open-pollinated variety) seeds and fertilizers to grow groundnut in order to increase her yield on her 0.0625 hectare plot of land.

Fatoumata has been growing groundnut for 20 years now for its nutritional value, since groundnut can be readily consumed by the family and is used as an ingredient in staple sauces, and also for its commercial value, since she sells groundnut at the market. Fatoumata says that "one sits down before laying down". With her expected increased yield and income, she is planning to start raising livestock and to increase the size of her arable land.  She also says that "the container to gather honey is always placed on top".  She also hopes to be able to cover her children's school fees and to build a house for her family.

loans.use: to purchase a package of OPV seeds and fertilizers in order to grow groundnuts.

loans.name: Hernán De Jesús

texts.es: Hernán de 19 años en su taller de mecánica realiza mantenimiento y reparación a varios tipos de vehículos automotores, desde muy niño aprendió de su padre quien también se dedicaba a esta actividad y lo ayudaba en las reparaciones que realizaba a los vehículos de sus clientes. Él identificó otra oportunidad de negocio y decidió arriesgarse e incursionar en la comercialización de yogurt, por ser una bebida láctea muy consumida en los hogares gracias a sus propiedades y aportes nutricionales consideró que era un producto apetecido por la comunidad. Su cadena de comercialización está dirigida a los colegios, las tiendas, restaurantes y vecinos del barrio donde reside en la Ciudad de Barranquilla.  Hoy en día cuenta con excelentes resultados e ingresos adicionales fruto de su esfuerzo y dedicación, en la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo para invertir en un refrigerador para conservar los yogures.  Esta inversión permitirá tener un stock de productos que responda más eficientemente a la demanda.  Sus metas a futuro son expandirse y tener varios puntos de venta, comprar su vivienda, formalizar la unión con su novia y continuar trabajando con mucho compromiso.
texts.en:
Hernan, 19, does maintenance and repairs on various types of cars in a mechanics workshop. He learned the trade since a very young age from his father who is also a mechanic. He used to help his dad with the repairs on his customers' cars.

He identified an opportunity for another business and decided to take a risk and start selling yogurt, because it's a dairy drink that's consumed in many homes thanks to its nutritional properties. He sees it as an appealing product for the community.

He directs his sales towards high schools, stores, restaurants and neighbors near him in the city of Barranquilla. He's had good results and today the fruit of his labor is an additional source of income.

He asks for a loan, his first from Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo, to buy a refrigerator to preserve the yogurts. This investment will allow him to keep a stock of products so that he can respond more efficiently to customer demand. His goals for the future are to expand and have several points of sale; to buy a home; to marry his girlfriend; and to continue working hard.

loans.use: to buy a refrigerator to preserve yogurt.

loans.name: Merci Group

texts.fr:
Faida fait partie du groupe  Merci  et  habite à  Bujumbura. Elle a 38 ans et est mariée à Jean, un coiffeur. Ensemble ils ont 6 enfants âgés de 5mois à 20 ans, dont  3 étudient.
Elle a sous sa charge sa mère et sa belle mère. 

Elle est coiffeuse  depuis  20 ans. 

Elle est   à son deuxième   crédit  à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’elle obtient, elle  va  augmenter son capital et acheter  une grande quantité de  mèches,et de produits  de beauté pour vendre son service,  afin  de gagner plus. 

Dans les prochaines  années, elle voudrait  acheter une parcelle, et voir ses enfants étudier.
texts.en:
Faida is a member of the Merci group and she lives in Bujumbura.  She is 38 years old and married to Jean, a hairdresser.  Faida and Jean have six children whose ages range from 5 months to 20 years old.  Three of their children go to school.  Faida has been working as a hairdresser for 20 years.

It is the second time that Faida is taking a loan from Turame.  With this new loan, financed by Kiva, she will be able to increase her capital and buy a large quantity of hair extensions and cosmetics to improve her business and increase her income.

In the coming years, she would like to buy a plot of land and see her children continue their studies.

loans.use: to buy a large quantity of hair extensions and cosmetic products to improve her business and increase her income.

loans.name: Ma. Christina

texts.en:
Ma. Christina is a hardworking entrepreneur, who has a general store business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 15,000 PHP through NWTF to buy more groceries to sell in her general store.

Ma. Christina has been in this business for 13 years. She also earns additional income from raising pigs.

Ma. Christina has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell in her general store

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is a 51-year-old woman, who is married to Julius. They are blessed with 7 children. 

She is a dairy farmer, and has been in this business for 10 years. She will use the loan to buy another dairy cow and dairy feed, and hopes this will enable her to get more milk to sell. Rebecca plans to use the anticipated profits to repay the loan and educate her children. 

Her future hopes are to improve her dairy farming, and make more income to support her family.

loans.use: To buy another dairy cow and dairy feed, which she hopes will give her more milk to sell, and enable her to support her family.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase a variety of goods

loans.name: Merries

texts.en:
Merries is a single woman with 3 children. She describes herself to be ambitious. 

Merries operates a retail business where she sells vegetables and fruits. She has been involved in this business for 8 years. Her business is located in a developing area, and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds. She will use the 50,000 KES loan to buy more stock of fruits and vegetables. 

Merries' business goal is to be a major supplier within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will meet her financial needs. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy more stock of fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase ingredients for cooking food

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a married woman. She has 6 children. She describes herself as ambitious. 

Susan operates a dairy farm where she sells milk. She has been involved in this business for 8 years. Her business is located in a developing area, and her primary customers are locals. 

Susan describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds. So, she will use the 40,000 KES loan to renovate her cowshed and buy more dairy cows. Her business goal is to have a chain of milk suppliers within 5 years. 

Susan hopes that, in the future, she will be able to meet her financial needs. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to renovate her cowshed and buy more dairy cows.

loans.name: Rasetrarivo

texts.fr:
Rasetrarivo est un père  très consciencieux de ses devoirs et obligations envers sa famille. Il était depuis 1982 dans le secteur  agricole de vente de bétail. Mais à partir l'année 2005, il se spécialisait dans la vente de porcelet. Il a des clients fixes qui sont des restaurateurs chinois qui lui commandent des porcelets déjà abattus et pré-préparé pour fabrication de cochon de lait.Il a environ 30 à 40 têtes de commande par semaine actuellement. Il voudrait encore trouver d'autres clients pour extension d'activité. 
Le moyen de transport du bétail est une bicyclette et il désire acquérir une voiture (bachée ou expresse).
Rasetrarivo a 49 ans et il est mariée, sa femme tient une petite épicerie pour l'aider à soutenir la famille. Ils ont trois enfants dont seulement le dernier reste à leur charge actuellement.
La famille de Rasetrarivo est simple et campagnarde mais souhaite avancer et améliorer leur niveau de vie tout en gardant leur simplicité.
texts.en:
Rasetrarivo is a father who is very conscientious of his duties and obligations for his family. In 1982, he was in the agriculture sector selling animals. But starting in 2005, he became specialized in selling piglets. He has fixed customers who are Chinese restauranteurs special-ordering from him slaughtered and pre-prepared piglets for making suckling pig. He has an order for about 30 to 40 piglets per week at this time. He would still like to find more customers for expanding his business. The animals are transported by means of a bicycle, and he would like to acquire a car (with a tarp covering or enclosed bed).

Rasetrarivo is 49 years old and married. His wife has a small grocery store to help him out in supporting the family. They have three children, of whom only the youngest is currently in their care. The Rasetrarivo’s are a simple and rustic family but wish to advance and improve their living conditions while keeping their simple ways.

loans.use: to purchase 17 piglets at 100,000 ariary per head

loans.name: Yvan

texts.es:
Yvan tiene 34 años de edad, vive en casa familiar y no cuenta con hijos bajo su poder, vive en el distrito de Pucará, una comunidad dedicada a la agricultura y ganadería que se encuenta ubicada en la provincia de Jaén, región Cajamarca, en la sierra norte de Perú.

El se dedica a brindar servicio de transporte público, cuenta con una mototaxi propia con la cual brinda este servicio, tiene más de 05 años de experiencia en el rubro, por lo que cuenta con clientela de la zona quienes dan buenas referencias personales y laborales de el, adicionalmente se dedica a las labores agrícolas. El préstamo lo va a invertir en arreglos y mantenimiento de su unidad móvil ya que se encuentra en mal estado, con esto el espera incrementar su nivel de ingresos lo que le va a permitir mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Yvan, 34, lives in his family's home and does not have any children in his care. He lives in the district of Pucara, a community dedicated to agriculture and cattle that is located in the province of Jaen, in the Cajamarca region in the northern mountains of Peru.

He provides transportation services with a motorcycle taxi that he owns. He has more than 5 years of experience in the field, and has customers in the area who offer good personal and professional references. He also works as a farmer.

This loan will be use to make repairs and perform maintenance on his mototaxi because it is in bad shape. With the repairs he hopes to increase his income so that he can improve his family's quality of life.

loans.use: to fix and maintain a motorcycle taxi that is in disrepair.

loans.name: Jostinah

texts.en:
Jostinah is a 58 year-old business lady from Soweto. She has 4 children, aged 30, 25, 17, and 16 years. As a divorcee, she has worked incredibly hard to support her kids through school. She has a construction business that does small-scale building projects within her area.

Working over 40 hours per week, Jostinah has already put a huge amount of energy into her business and has managed to employ others. However, her business has greatly slowed down due to a lack of sufficient revenue. She is therefore requesting a loan to buy new building materials such as cement, plaster, iron sheets for roofing, and tins of paint. With the new resources she will be able to meet customer demand.

When asked about the future of her business, Jostinah said, "I want to help more and more people move into new, affordable, and lovely houses."

loans.use: to buy new stock of building materials.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to finish digging a hole for the latrine and to build a latrine, which he lacks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow for milk production so as to both provide his customers with milk and earn more profits to support his family.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more stock of maize cereals to sell in the market and meet client food supply demands.

loans.name: Araceli

texts.es:
Araceli tiene 40 años de edad, es separada, vive con sus hijos en casa propia en una comunidad grande en la zona rural del distrito de Lagunas, provincia de Chiclayo, región Lambayeque, en la costa norte de Perú. Los pobladores de esta comunidad se dedican principalmente al comercio y crianza de animales.

Ella se dedica a brindar servicio de transporte público en su mototaxi, se dedica a este negocio desde hace más de 3 años por lo que cuenta con experiencia y con clientes fijos quienes dan buenas referencias de ella. Solicita préstamo para la compra de una mototaxi nueva ya que quiere ampliar su negocio, de esta manera ella espera obtener más ingresos y hacer crecer su negocio lo que le permitirá poder mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Araceli is 40 years old.  She’s separated and lives in her own home in a large rural community in the Lagunas district, Chiclayo province, Lambayeque region, on the northern coast of Peru.  The residents here mainly raise animals and work as merchants.

She provides transportation with her moto-taxi, has done so for more than three years, and has steady customers who provide her with good references.  She is asking for a loan to buy a new moto-taxi because she wants to expand her business and she hopes to increase her income and improve her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: to buy a new moto-taxi.

loans.name: Luis

texts.en:
Luis is very thankful to those who supported him recently with his previous 35,000 PHP loan. With this amount, he was able to improve his business. He was also able to help his family and provide for their daily necessities. 

Today, Luis would like to ask again for assistance from you. With an amount of 40,000 PHP, he could add capital to his business. He will use this loan to both pay for the maintenance of his computers and buy other things needed for the improvement of his shop. He hopes that you can help him with this loan. He knows that your helping hands can really change lives like his. 

Someday, he dreams of growing his business and being successful in life without thinking of any debts. He meets up every week with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work and to draw strength and inspiration from the word of God he studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group comprises 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to both pay for the maintenance of his computers and buy other things needed for the improvement of his shop.

loans.name: Nitugumane Group

texts.fr:
Pascal  fait partie du groupe  Nitugumana et  habite à  Bujumbura. Il a 40 ans et est marié à Dénise, une commerçante. Ensemble ils ont 5 enfants âgés de 1à 14 ans, dont  4 étudient. 

Il  fait le commerce de limonade, du haricot, du riz,…dans sa boutique  depuis  7 ans. 

Il est à  son troisième   crédit  à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’il obtient, il  va  augmenter son capital et acheter  une grande quantité de limonade (4 caisses) à revendre pour gagner plus. 

Dans les prochaines  années, il voudrait voir ses enfants étudier.
texts.en:
Pascal is part of the group Nitugumana and lives in  Bujumbura. He is 40 years old and married to Dénise, a merchant. Together they have five children, aged 1 to 14 years old, of whom four are students. 

Pascal has been doing commerce in lemonade, beans, rice… in his shop for seven years. 

He is on his 3rd Turame loan. With the KIVA loan he is obtaining, he is going to increase his capital and to purchase a large amount of lemonade (4 cases) to resell, so as to earn more.

In the years to come, he would like to see his children educated.

loans.use: to purchase a large amount of lemonade (4 cases) to resell, so as to earn more

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase pasta (spaghetti)

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase Wax 'pagne' cloth

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer for use in his farm

loans.name: Joyous Group

texts.en:
“A journey of a thousand miles begins with one step.” This summarizes how Lillian’s business has evolved since 1998. Lillian started her business in 1998 by selling tomatoes and vegetables along the roadside or by her gate. As her children grew, so did the needs of the family, making it hard for the father of the family to cope alone. Husband and wife had to provide food, clothing and education for their minors, developing from a small vegetable stall to a good "tuck" shop business selling different grocery items. Her business has over the years enabled her to educate her children up to tertiary level, with another now a nurse.

The formation of Joyous Group arose from the needs of four hardworking women to upgrade their businesses. The group attended training sessions at Thrive for about a month, and the lessons were an eye opener. Lillian admitted that she used to use business money for personal use, did not record her transactions and did not balance her books. The Thrive training has brought changes to the way that she is doing business. She feels that she is on her way to being a much better businesswoman. With her Kiva loan, Lillian plans to fully stock her "tuck" shop so that there is no product that is missing when clients come to buy.

In the future, Lillian is planning to grow her business from a "tuck" shop to a proper shop.

loans.use: to increase her stock for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stock of soap, flour, bread, milk, sugar and vegetables

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy new motorcycle spare parts for use for better servicing operations

loans.name: Benita

texts.en:
Benita would like you to know her full appreciation and thanksgiving because her previous loan has indeed helped her in buying additional products for her business. She faithfully repaid an amount of PHP 25,000, which she had used in buying additional products for her inventory. 

But still, she would like to improve her sales more. With this, she is humbly requesting for another PHP 20,000 loan, which she will utilize to purchase more merchandise products. Preferably, her customers will likely buy more items since she offers low cost products of cosmetics, clothing, and other products. 

In some time at the future, she wants to develop their kind of living and just to simply be happy. She meets every week with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional supplies and merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Wousgo Nooma Group

texts.fr: Abibou, membre représentatif est une femme battante, veuve et mère de 5 enfants tous scolarisés. Cette brave dame fait le commerce de céréales et cela fait 12 ans qu'elle mène cette activité. le groupe d'Abibou est à son 13ème contrat avec ACFIME, mais il a toujours fait les remboursements à la bonne date. Abibou a besoin de ce prêt pour acheter du maïs, du petit mil, du haricot,... pour vendre et ce se faire un bénéfice. Après ses ventes, son bénéfice lui permettra de s'occuper de ses enfants( soins médicaux, nourriture, habillement,...)tout en continuant ses activités.
texts.en:
Abibou, a representative member, is a determined woman, a widow, and the mother of five children, all in school. This good and honest woman does commerce in grains and has been in this business for 12 years. 

Abibou’s group is on its 13th contract with ACFIME, and it has always made its payments on time. Abibou has need of this loan to purchase corn, pearl millet, beans, … to sell and thus make a profit. After her sales, her profit will enable her to take care of her children (medical care, food, clothing, …) while continuing her business.

loans.use: to purchase grains (corn, beans, pearl millet,...) to resell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase grains (millet)

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase spaghetti

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more drinks for sale, in order to pay for schooling expenses

loans.name: Jema

texts.en:
This is Jema's request for her second Kiva loan. The first loan helped Jema to buy varieties of clothes for her shop and cover house hold expenses for her family.

The second loan will help Jema to expand her business by increasing women clothes in her shop.  Jema has a future plan of providing stationary services in her community.

loans.use: to expand her business by increasing women clothes in her shop

loans.name: Mwajuma

texts.en:
Mwajuma is a 21-year-old living with her family of six in the Morogoro district. She is an aspiring entrepreneur who performs volunteer service as a Camfed Learner Guide. She teaches life skills to her students in the nearby secondary school, where her lessons focus on effective communication and building her students’ confidence.

Mwajuma would like to start a business with a Kiva 800,000 TZS loan. She will use the money to buy clothing and open her own fashion shop. She plans to use the profits she earns to support her sister in providing basic home needs and to pursue her own education further.

The interest on Mwajuma's “social-interest” loan will be repaid through her weekly two-and-a-half hours of volunteering at the secondary school, which is so valuable for Camfed’s younger students.

loans.use: to buy items of clothing and open her own fashion shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy women's clothing and launch her own store in her village

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy colorful dresses to launch her own women’s clothing store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fashion items with which to launch her clothing business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand her women's clothes business by renting a stall

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy women’s clothes for selling and to participate in the business world

loans.name: Mericiana

texts.en: Mericiana is a 20-year-old restaurant owner, living with her parents and her child in the Morogoro district. Her work involves running her small restaurant business in order to make a little profit for supporting her family. She is now requesting a Kiva loan to buy kitchen utensils with which to expand her restaurant business. Mericiana plans to use the profit she earns to pursue her dream of opening a large restaurant in a year's time and of providing a valuable service to her society.

loans.use: to buy kitchen utensils and expand her restaurant.

loans.name: Salima

texts.en:
Salima is a woman who lives with her husband and is 34 years old. She has three children. 

Salima is a Cama member also deals with buying and selling clothes especially for ladies [women], like kanga and vitenge. She is going well with her business. 

Salima gets income through her business which enables her and her youngest.  Also she uses her profit to pay school fees for her children.

She is requesting a Kiva loan in order to expand her business by adding shoes and dresses. Salima has a dream of having a big shop of clothes after two years. Her best vision is to save money for the future.

loans.use: To expand her business by adding clothes and shoes

loans.name: Saida

texts.en:
LOAN USE: To buy a new fashion line for her clothing business.

Saida is a 32-year-old clothing saleswoman, living with her husband and their three children in the Morogoro district. Her work involves buying and selling clothes within her local community in order to pay school fees for her child. On top of this, she encourages students supported by Camfed to join the Cama network. 

She is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to buy a new line of fashionable clothing to sell in her shop. Saida plans to use the profit she earns to continue supporting her child's educational expenses, and pursue her dream of opening a large clothing retailer.

loans.use: to buy a new fashion line for her clothing business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more colorful printed dresses and skirts to expand her clothing business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a greater variety of clothing in order to expand her ladies’ clothing business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more kitchen equipment to scale up her restaurant

loans.name: Dotto

texts.en: Dotto is a 35-year-old motorcycle-transport businesswoman, and she has four children and is married. She lives with her husband. Dotto also helps other vulnerable schoolchildren with their needs. Dotto's business rents motorcycles to customers so that they can transport themselves around the local area. She is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to buy another motorcycle so she can increase her business's capacity and profit. Dotto plans to use the profit she earns to pay for school fees to send her children to a better school.

loans.use: To buy another motorcycle to increase her business's capacity and profit

loans.name: Cheka

texts.en: Cheka is 23 years old, and she is not married. She lives with her parents in the Morogoro District. She has made a commitment to educating secondary school students in life skills and self-awareness for at least two and a half hours per week. Also, Cheka has a business selling charcoal. She started this business in order to solve the challenges facing her and her family of not having enough funds for household expenses. The profit Cheka gets through this business is used by her family for household expenses and to purchase more charcoal for sale. She is now submitting her request for a soft loan from Kiva in order to build a simple store for selling charcoal and to expand her business.

loans.use: to build a store for her charcoal business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to start a business of selling women's clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy new varieties of fish to fry and sell from her stall.

loans.name: Nuru

texts.en:
Nuru is a 22-year-old entrepreneur and volunteer Camfed Learner Guide, living with her mother and brother in the Morogoro district. As a volunteer Camfed Learner Guide, she teaches life skills to students in her local secondary school, including lessons on effective communication and personal confidence. 

She is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to launch her own charcoal business, as she has observed that nobody else is selling charcoal in her village. Nuru plans to use the profits earned to pay the school fees and daily expenses for her young brother. The interest on Nuru’s “social-interest” loan will be repaid through her weekly two and a half hours of volunteering, which are so valuable for Camfed’s younger students.

loans.use: to launch her own charcoal business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to renovate her store and buy oil to tend to her grinding machine.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy clothes and launch her own fashion business near her home.

loans.name: Kulwa

texts.en: Kulwa having repaid her first loan in full (with which she decorated her salon and built a house for her family). Kulwa is now applying for a second loan with which to employ a community member as another member of staff, and to buy more cosmetic products. Through her lessons as a Learner Guide, Kulwa encourages students to find their own strengths, and to think about how to create a better world. Kulwa thinks that Kiva loans offer an excellent program for business women and she greatly enjoys her work. Kulwa will use her profits to finish work on her house. The interest on Kulwa’s “social-interest” loan will be repaid through her weekly two and a half hours of volunteering, which are so valuable for Camfed’s younger students.

loans.use: to purchase dryers, steamers and modern beauty products

loans.name: Zuwena

texts.en:
Zuwena is a 19-year-old entrepreneur and volunteer Camfed Learner Guide living in the Bagamoyo district. As a way of giving back to her community, Zuwena volunteers as a Camfed Learner Guide, teaching life skills to her students in the nearby secondary school. Her lessons focus on effective communication and on building her students’ confidence. 

She is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to buy sugar, salt, flour, rice and cooking oil with which to launch her own home foods store. Zuwena plans to use the profits earned to support her family’s daily financial burdens, and to further reinvest in her business. The interest on her “social-interest” loan will be repaid through her weekly two and a half hours of volunteering, which are so valuable for Camfed’s younger students.

loans.use: to buy sugar, salt, flour and rice to launch a home foods store

loans.name: Zawadi

texts.en: Zawadi is 21 years old and lives in Bagamoyo district. She is single and lives with her parents. Zawadi is a Camfed learner guide who volunteers to work with children in secondary school. She teaches them about the importance of education and how they can help each other’s learning to improve their learning performance. Zawadi is a tailor, but she does not have a machine. She has requested a Kiva loan to buy a tailoring machine and other material, such as cloth, in order to start her business. She will use the profit to expand her business and to help her family with basic needs.

loans.use: to buy a tailoring machine and other material

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
LOAN USE: To start a women’s clothes business.

Halima is a girl of 19 years old. She lives with her parents. She is a Camfed Learner Guide and volunteers to teach life skills to students.

She requested a Kiva loan to start a women’s clothes business in her community. She will use her profit to expand her business by increasing varieties of clothes in her shop. Halima will also buy home products for her family.

The social interest will be paid as Halima volunteers to deliver life skills to secondary students; this is so valuable to Camfed.

loans.use: to start a women's clothes business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stock to launch her own stall in the local market.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to launch her own grocery business

loans.name: Khadija

texts.en: Khadija is a 29-year-old store owner, living with her husband and their three children in the Kibaha district. Her work involves running her own store in her village. She is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to buy a sufficient variety of products to get her store up and running again. Khadija plans to use the profit she earns to support her family's costs of living and further invest in more products for her store.

loans.use: to buy a sufficient variety of home products to get her store up and running again

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to launch a venture in selling charcoal

loans.name: Mwajuma

texts.en: Mwajuma is a 23-year-old restaurant owner living with her husband and their child in the Kibaha district. Her work involves running her own restaurant in her village. She is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to buy chairs, stools and high-quality food to boost her restaurant's business. Mwajuma plans to use the profit she earns to support her family's cost of living. She hopes to become a great business woman if she is awarded a Kiva loan.

loans.use: to buy chairs, stools and high-quality ingredients to boost her restaurant's business.

loans.name: Zawadi

texts.en: Zawadi is a 21-year-old entrepreneur living with her husband and child in the Kibaha district. As she currently doesn't have her own business, Zawadi is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to launch a venture in selling charcoal in her local village. She will use the loan to buy an initial stock of charcoal with which to launch her own business. Zawadi plans to use the profit she earns to send her child to school, support her family's basic domestic needs, and further invest in her new business.

loans.use: to launch her charcoal selling business

loans.name: Happiness

texts.en: Happiness is a 20-year-old entrepreneur and volunteer Camfed Learner Guide, living with her mother (her father has passed away) in the Bagamoyo district. Through her lessons as a Learner Guide, she encourages students to find their own strengths, and to think about how to create a better world. As she currently doesn't have her own business, Happiness is now requesting a Kiva loan to launch a venture selling women's clothing. She will use the loan to buy various women's clothes with which to start her business. Happiness plans to use the profit she earns to invest in men's clothes too, and to cover her family's daily living costs. The interest on her “social-interest” loan will be repaid through Happinesses' weekly two and a half hours of volunteering, which are so valuable for Camfed’s younger students.

loans.use: to launch a venture selling women's clothing.

loans.name: Mwanaidi

texts.en: Mwanaidi is a 27-year-old entrepreneur and volunteer Camfed Core trainer who lives in the Kibaha district with her husband and their three children. As she currently doesn't have her own business, Mwanaidi is requesting a Kiva loan to launch a business selling home electrical appliances. She will use her loan to buy television sets, fans, and radios for her business. Mwanaidi plans to use the profit she earns to send her children to school and improve her own educational status.

loans.use: to buy television sets, fans and radios to launch her electrical appliance business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stock to start her food stall

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to launch her electrical store.

loans.name: Sauda

texts.en:
LOAN USE: to invest in more kitchen equipment and food to expand her restaurant business

Sauda is a 26-year-old restaurant owner living with her husband and their child in the Kibaha district. Her work involves running her own small restaurant near her home. She is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to invest in more kitchen equipment and food with which to expand her restaurant business. Sauda plans to use the profit she earns to support her family with food and clothing costs and to send her child to school. The interest on her “social-interest” loan will be repaid through Sauda's volunteering to recruit other students in the cama network, which are so valuable for Camfed’s young women.

loans.use: to invest in more kitchen equipment and food to expand her restaurant business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to open a clothing business, so that she can pay for a higher education

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
LOAN USE: To buy stock and start her own charcoal business

Sophia is a 30-year-old entrepreneur, living with her husband and their three children in the Kibaha district. She particularly helps disabled children. 

As she currently doesn't have her own business, Sophia is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to launch a venture in selling charcoal. She will use the loan to buy an initial stock of charcoal with which to launch her own business. 

Sophia plans to use the profit she earns to solve her family's financial troubles, and also support other needy children in the community. She wants to transform from a dependent, to an independent woman.

loans.use: To buy stock and start her own charcoal business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to launch her cosmetics and clothing business

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
LOAN USE: To buy a variety of grocery products to expand her store's business

Fatuma is a 30-year-old grocery-store owner and volunteers to recruit new Cama members in her district living with her husband and their two children in the Kibaha district. 

Her work involves running her own grocery store near her home. She is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to buy a variety of grocery products to expand her store's business. Fatuma plans to use the profit she earns to pursue her dream of becoming a great business woman. 

The interest on her “social-interest” loan will be repaid through Fatuma's weekly two and a half hours of volunteering, which are so valuable for Camfed’s younger students.

loans.use: to buy a variety of grocery products to expand her store's business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to launch her own grocery business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to launch a venture in selling clothing. The profits will partly be used to help her parents daily needs

loans.name: Maua

texts.en:
LOAN USE:  to buy new products to sell and launch her own market stall.

Maua is a 25-year-old entrepreneur and volunteer Camfed Learner Guide, living with her husband and child in the Kibaha district. Volunteering as a Learner Guide, she teaches life skills to students in her local secondary school, including lessons on effective communication and personal confidence. 

As she currently doesn't have her own business, Maua is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to launch a venture in a small market store. She will use the loan to buy her first stock to sell for a profit at the local market. Maua plans to use the profit she earns to support her family's financial needs. She dreams of one day becoming a world-famous businesswoman. 

The interest on her “social-interest” loan will be repaid through Maua's weekly two and a half hours of volunteering, which are so valuable for Camfed’s younger students.

loans.use: to buy new products to sell and launch her own market stall

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to launch her own grocery business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy beauty products with which to launch her own cosmetics store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to launch a venture in selling women and men`s clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To construct her own large hut to house her restaurant business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to launch a grocery business

loans.name: Usichungue

texts.en:
Usichungue is a 33-year-old volunteer Camfed Learner Guide, living with her husband and four children in the Rufiji district. Through her lessons as a Learner Guide, Usichungue encourages local secondary school students to find their own strengths, and to think about how to create a better world. 

She has been delighted to see local women participating in socioeconomic affairs, and is now requesting her own Kiva loan in order to launch a local cosmetics business. Usichungue plans to use the profits earned to pay her children’s school fees, to support her husband and to cover household expenses. 

The interest on Usichungue’s “social-interest” loan will be repaid through her weekly two and a half hours of volunteering, which are so valuable for Camfed’s younger students.

loans.use: to launch her own cosmetics business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to start a clothing business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to start a business of hiring bicycles.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to start a pub business

loans.name: Anna

texts.en: Anna is a 22-year-old entrepreneur and volunteer Camfed Learner Guide, living with her child and parents in the Kilombero district. Volunteering as a Learner Guide, she teaches life skills to her students in the nearby secondary school. Her lessons focus on effective communication and on building her students’ confidence.  As she currently doesn't have her own business, Anna is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to launch a venture in selling local fruit from her own stall. She will use the loan to build a stall and buy fruit to sell from it. Anna plans to use the profit she earns to support her basic domestic needs and to send her child to school. The interest on her “social-interest” loan will be repaid through Anna's weekly two-and-a-half hours of volunteering, which are so valuable for Camfed’s younger students.

loans.use: to build a stall and buy fruits to sell from it

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is 35 years old. She is not married and lives with her four children. She is a volunteer in the ward where she lives, by encouraging those form 4 leavers, drop-outs from school, due to pregnancy and other reasons, to join in with the Cama network.  There they can learn different activities and how to live and be economically independent. She is also explaining Cama and its meaning to all new Cama members.

Although she has a family business,she has requested a loan from Kiva, in order to open her own clothing business. The profit from her business she will use to send her children to school and help vulnerable students by buying them uniforms and paying school fees.  She can use the profit to encourage  parents in her village to start cooking food for students.  Fatuma's dream is to live a better life.

loans.use: To launch her own business venture, independent from her family business

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
LOAN USE: To increase commodities in her business.

Asha (28) is married and lives with her two children. She runs a grocery store business. She requested a loan from Kiva in order to increase commodities in her business. 

She usually encourages students to attend school regularly and encourages the former Camfed beneficiary students to join in the Cama network and also  to introduce the Cama network and principles to all new members. 

She plans to use the profit from the Kiva loan to find more students who finished form four (4) and encourage those who are supported by Camfed to join Cama.

loans.use: to increase commodities in her grocery

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more kitchen utensils in order to expand her restaurant business

loans.name: Adrofina

texts.en:
LOAN USE: To rent a store from which to run her clothing business.

Adrofina is a 20-year-old clothing trader who is living with her mother in the Kilombero district. From selling clothes door-to-door for the last 10 months, Adrofina has paid for her mother’s food and medical expenses, and has also donated 500 shillings per month to support needy primary school students since 2014. 

She is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to rent a store in which she can settle and sell her clothes for greater profit. Adrofina plans to use the profits earned to further develop her business.

loans.use: to rent a store from which to run her clothing business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy her first stock of rice to launch her own business.

loans.name: Stela

texts.en:
Stela is a 34-year-old farmer and volunteer Camfed Learner Guide, living as a single mother with her two children in the Kilombero district. As well as  working the land for agriculture, she uses her lessons as a Learner Guide to encourage students to find their own strengths and to think about how they can create a better world. 

She is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to buy bicycles and so launch her own bike-hiring business. Stela plans to use the profit she earns to pay school fees for her children. The interest on her “social-interest” loan will be repaid through Stela's weekly two and a half hours of volunteering, which are so valuable for Camfed’s younger students.

loans.use: to buy bicycles and launch her own bike-hiring business

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
LOAN USE: To buy more charcoal to restock her store

Rosemary is a 30-year-old charcoal trader, living with her husband and three children in the Kilombero district. She pays for her dependents’ school and medical expenses through the charcoal business which she has been running in her village for the past four years. This has also allowed her to support needy students by donating 500 shillings per month to them for the past five years. 

She requests a Kiva loan to increase charcoal in her store. 

Rosemary plans to use the profits earned to cover household expenses for her family.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to restock her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand her business and to order more fabrics

loans.name: Beata

texts.en:
LOAN USE: To buy soft drinks with which to open her own store.

Beata is a 22-year-old entrepreneur and volunteer Camfed Learner Guide, living with her parents in the Kilombero district. Through her lessons as a Learner Guide, Beata encourages local secondary school students to find their own strengths and to think about how to create a better world.

She is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to open a soft drinks store, where she intends to work twelve hours per day, six days per week. Beata plans to use the profits earned to expand her business to one day become a wholesaler, and to support all of her family’s financial needs in the process.

The interest on Beatrice’s “social-interest” loan will be repaid through her weekly two and a half hours of volunteering, which are so valuable for Camfed’s younger students.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks with which to open her own store

loans.name: Zalia

texts.en:
Zalia is a 34-year-old business woman, volunteer teacher and mother of three. Zalia has four dependents - her mother and children - whose medical, school, and daily expenses she covers through the clothing business she has run for three years. 

Zalia runs this business by herself, with no hired help. If she gets a Kiva loan, Zalia’s dream is to expand her business by purchasing varieties of clothes. She intends to use the profit accumulated from her loan to expand her business, and to better support herself, her siblings and other students.

loans.use: to expand her business by purchasing varieties of clothes

loans.name: Yohana

texts.en:
LOAN USE: To expand her business by buying pig food.

Yohana (35) is not married and she has two children. They depend on her for everything like daily basic needs, medical expenses, and food and school expenses.

She has volunteered to her society since 2007 to support the siblings’ students Safe Net Fund, whereby students receive materials like exercise books, pens, pencils etc.

She has had a business of pig keeping for about five years and a month to now. She is doing it by herself, and she didn't hire anyone.

She requests a loan from Kiva to expand her business by buying pig food. She intends to use her accumulated profit from Kiva to expand more her business.

loans.use: to expand her business by buying pig food

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy various fashionable clothing items and launch her own store.

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en:
LOAN USE: To buy more bicycles for her business
Sofia is a 33-year-old bicycle-business owner and volunteers to recruit students supported by Camfed to join Cama network in her district. Sofia lives with her child in the Kilombero district. She has independently run her own bicycle hiring business for the past four years. She is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to buy more bicycles and to expand her business. Sofia plans to use the profits earned to meet her siblings’ and her own economic needs.

loans.use: to buy more bicycles for her business.

loans.name: Sharifa

texts.en:
LOAN USE: To expand her business by purchasing rice in bulk and selling it at retail

Sharifa is 32 years old. She is married and has two children. Sharifa is a Cama member in Kiombero district. She has volunteered in her society since 2007.

Sharifa runs a business of selling rice in her area. She requested a Kiva loan to expand her business by purchasing rice in bulk and selling it at retail. The profit obtained from the loan will help Sharifa renovate her store and pay for household expenses for her family.

loans.use: to expand her business by purchasing rice in bulk and selling it at retail.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to launch her own clothing business.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
LOAN USE: To expand her business by increasing tomatoes and onions in her food market.

Rose is 35 years old, married, and she has four children.  She is a Camfed member from Kilombero district. Rose has small market stall business. She is selling tomatoes, onions, potatoes etc. She respects everyone in her community. She uses her profits for buying basic needs for herself and her siblings. 

She is requesting Kiva loan to expand her business by increasing the number of tomatoes and onions in her food market. She intends to use her profits accumulated from Kiva to expand her business and to help herself in social expenses.

loans.use: to expand her business by increasing tomatoes and onions in her market stall.

loans.name: Pendo

texts.en:
LOAN USE: to buy kitchen utensils and to hire an employee to boost her restaurant business.

Pendo is a 22-year-old, restaurant owner and volunteer Camfed Learner Guide, living with her parents and younger sister in the Kilombero district. Her work involves independently running her own restaurant, which she has done for the last seven months without any hired help. She is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to buy more kitchen utensils and to hire another employee, in order to boost her restaurant business. 

Pendo plans to use the profits she earns to reinvest and expand her business further, as well as to continue supporting her sister's and her own daily expenses. The interest on her “social-interest” loan will be repaid through Pendo's weekly two and a half hours of volunteering, which are so valuable for Camfed’s younger students.

loans.use: to buy kitchen utensils and to hire an employee to boost her restaurant business.

loans.name: Nuru

texts.en:
LOAN USE: To develop her restaurant business.

Nuru is a 30-year-old, restaurant owner and volunteer teacher, supporting her mother and two children in the Kilombero district. As a Camfed Learner Guide, Nuru volunteers for two and half hours per week to teach life skills to local students. For the past nine years, her lessons have ranged from teaching effective communication, to building her students’ confidence. 

Nuru has run her own restaurant business for the past three years. Her dream is now to expand her business with the help of a Kiva loan, in order to make greater profits. She plans to use these profits to build a strong house and to support poorer students in her community.

loans.use: to develop her restaurant business.

loans.name: Matrida

texts.en:
LOAN USE:  to expand her business by keeping rice in her store.

Matrida is 25 years old, married, and she has two children. Matrida is a Cama member. She has three dependents, her mother and two children. She helps them with medical and food. Matrida has volunteered to her society since 2010 to support the sibling’s student for Safe Net Fund, by contributing five hundred per month. 

Matrida has a buying and selling rice business. She requests a Kiva loan to expand her business by keeping rice in her store. The profits will help her to pay household expenses for her family.

loans.use: to expand her business by keeping rice in her store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy equipment and open a hairdressing salon.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fish with which to launch her own fish-selling business.

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en:
LOAN USE: to buy clothes with which to launch her own clothing business.

Jamila is a 29-year-old, farmer and volunteer Camfed Learner Guide, living with her husband and two children in the Kilombero district. Her work involves agricultural farming around her home. Also, volunteering as a Camfed Learner Guide, she teaches life skills to students in her local secondary school, including lessons on effective communication and personal confidence. 

She is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to buy clothes, and so to launch her own clothing business. Jamila plans to use the profits she earns to pay school fees so her children can study, and to build a strong house for herself and her family. The interest on her “social-interest” loan will be repaid through Jamila's weekly two and a half hours of volunteering, which are so valuable for Camfed’s younger students.

loans.use: to buy clothes with which to launch her own clothing business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothes with which to launch her own fashion business.

loans.name: Haruna

texts.en:
LOAN USE: To buy products with which to launch her own market stall.

Haruna is a 25-year-old, entrepreneur and volunteer Camfed Learner Guide, living with her parents in the Kilombero district. Volunteering as a Learner Guide, she teaches life skills to her students in the nearby secondary school. Her lessons focus on effective communication and on building her students’ confidence.  

As she currently doesn't have her own business, Haruna is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to launch a venture in the local market by opening her own small market stall. She will use the loan to buy products with which to launch her own market stall. Haruna plans to use the profits she earns to build herself a strong house and support her daily expenses. The interest on her “social-interest” loan will be repaid through her weekly two and a half hours of volunteering, which are so valuable for Camfed’s younger students.

loans.use: to buy products with which to launch her own market stall.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy detergent as capital to launch her own business

loans.name: Happiness

texts.en: Happiness is 32 years old and a single mother of one child. Happiness lives in the Kilombero district and has been a Cama borrower since 2010. She takes care of her child and her parents, providing basic needs like medical care, food and school expenses. Happiness buys and sells rice, running the business herself. She requests a Kiva loan to expand her business by purchasing rice in bulk and selling retail to make a profit. She intends to use her profit to help herself and her parents improve their socioeconomic position.

loans.use: to expand her business by purchasing rice in bulk and selling it retail

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy enough charcoal to re-stock her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to launch a venture selling groceries in her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy sewing materials and so expand her tailoring business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to launch a venture in selling clothes

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
Emilia is a 29-year-old tailor and volunteer teacher who is supporting her mother, two children and two younger sisters. As a Camfed Learner Guide, Emilia volunteers for two and half hours per week to teach life skills to local students. In her lessons, she helps pupil to better understand themselves and to have self-confidence. On top of this, Emilia works ten hours and six days per week in her clothing store. 

With a Kiva loan, Emilia intends to expand her business and so to earn more profit. In this way, she wants to set an example to her society.

loans.use: to boost her tailoring business to obtain a greater profit and set a good example

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris is a 24-year-old grocery-store owner and volunteer Camfed Learner Guide, living with her husband, their child, her mother and her three younger siblings in the Kilombero district. Her work involves running a grocery store from which she sells a variety of home products. Her business profited from Doris's first Kiva loan, which also helped her to pass her exams. She also volunteers as a Camfed Learner Guide, teaching life-skills to her students in the nearby Secondary School. Her lessons focus on effective communication and on building her students’ confidence.  

She is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to buy stationery to increase the range of home products which she sells from her store. Doris plans to use the profit she earns to build a strong house for herself and her family. The interest on her “social-interest” loan will be repaid through Doris's weekly two and a half hours of volunteering, which are so valuable for Camfed’s younger students.

loans.use: to improve her grocery store’s variety with stationary and home products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cosmetic products and rent a room from which to run business

loans.name: Debora

texts.en: Debora is a 32-year-old farmer living with her husband and their two children in the Kilombero district. Debora now is requesting a loan from Kiva in order to start her own bicycle-hiring business. This business will help Debora to improve transport options for local villagers. Profit obtained from the business will be used for domestic needs including food, shelter and clothing, as well as to send her children to school and to expand her bicycle business further.

loans.use: To launch her own bicycle hire business

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Her work involves buying and selling cosmetics and - since her first Kiva loan - selling women's clothing too. She is now requesting a Kiva loan in order to buy a greater variety of women's clothing and cosmetics to boost her store's business. 

Christina plans to use the profit she earns to build a house for her family, as well as supporting their basic food, clothing and shelter needs.. The interest on her “social-interest” loan will be repaid through Christina's weekly two and a half hours of volunteering, which are so valuable for Camfed’s younger students.

loans.use: to buy a greater variety of women's clothing and cosmetics to boost her store's business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy salon cosmetics

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
LOAN USE: To buy more groceries and so increase her store turnover.

Catherine is a 30-year-old grocer living with her husband and two children in the Kilombero district. She runs her own grocery shop selling soft drinks, water, cooking oil, and juice. 

Catherine requests a Kiva loan to expand her grocery by increasing products.  She plans to use the profits earned to become a financially independent woman. 

The interest on Catherine’s “social-interest” loan will be repaid through her volunteering to recruit Camfed`s supported students to join the CAMA network which is so valuable for Camfed’s younger women.

loans.use: to expand her grocery by increasing products

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is a 30-year-old mother, volunteer, and businesswoman from Tanzania. She volunteers as a Camfed Learner Guide at the local secondary school. She teaches life skills to young students, including lessons on effective communication and personal confidence. 

Lucy is also a tailor and sews bed sheets to sell to people in her village. She has been running her business for five years, and she is known in her village as the woman who produces good quality bed sheets. Her business allows her to provide food for her family. 

This is Lucy's second loan from Kiva. Her first loan was used to buy a good electronic sewing machine and materials to make the bed sheets. The sewing machine was extremely helpful to Lucy as she has been able to make the bed sheets faster and satisfy her growing customer base. 

Lucy is now requesting her second Kiva loan, so she can open up her own tailoring shop. The interest on Lucy’s “social-interest” loan will be repaid through her weekly two and a half hours of volunteering, which are so valuable for Camfed’s younger students.

loans.use: to open a store from which to sell her tailored products.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more cloth to tailor and sell to her customers.

loans.name: Helena

texts.en:
Helena is a 23-year-old fashion tradeswoman, living with her uncle and sibling in the Kilosa district. She sells and rents clothes to various customers in order to generate income to support her sibling’s basic school needs. 

Helena volunteers as a Camfed alumni member, encouraging students supported by Camfed to join the Cama network. She will use this loan to buy crucial stock for her growing clothing business. Helena plans to use the profits earned to continue to help her sibling and to reinvest in her growing business.

loans.use: To buy crucial stock for her growing clothing business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to launch a venture in mobile money transfer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy new products to sell from her market stall with profits used to improve her family's welfare

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester (22), is living with her parents and her siblings. She is volunteering in her nearby Secondary School to help Learners to attend School regularly without missing and to make them concentrate with their studies. 

She did not have any business but she intends to open up a shop. She requests a Loan from Kiva so as to rent a room and open a grocery store. She plans to get income to help her parents and serve her family home basic needs and she plan to be an international wholesaler and to open another business and after all to re-sit her form 4 national examination

loans.use: to rent a room and open a grocery store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to launch a venture in her food market with her own stall

loans.name: Dorice

texts.en:
LOAN USE: to launch her CD library near her community.

Dorice, 22, is not married and she has a child. She is living with her parents and her child, who all depend on her to help in providing for their household needs and other responsibilities. 

She supports her family from the salary she gets from a shop where she works as a shopkeeper. She usually engages in renting movie tapes, CDs, and DVDs and plans to improve her business by having enough CDs and having a room where her customers will find her there. She requests a loan from Kiva to launch her CD library near her community. 

With the profits she earns, she intends to open another small business and to support her daily life. She has hopes for a future of being a big businesswoman.

loans.use: to launch her CD library near her community

loans.name: Maisha

texts.en:
